ratings.question_text: Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: we used online chat boards through canvas as well.

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course? (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Thorough understanding of arguments common in postcolonial African literature studies
A way of thinking critically with texts as sociological, historical, and artistic forms of expression.
Writing a longer paper on a more focused topic. Engaging with criticism and theory while still making an original arguement
a much deeper understanding of African literature and how realism exists and is challenged in it.
Through discussion with Professor Newell and my peers, I gained a grasp of themes and discussions pertinent in contemporary African literature and postcolonial theory.
I learned more about contemporary African authors, as well as a greater, more expansive sense of what "realism" can mean in African literature.
it was a great survey of English language African literature and postcolonial criticism that is woefully and systemically under-prioritized elsewhere in the English department.

I continued to practice the skill of critically analyzing literature, and I grew in my ability to think about questions of genre.  The readings for this course all stretched my thinking about what it means to challenge realism, and I was also exposed to different ways of reading literature (reading from an ecocritical standpoint, for example).
eh

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved? (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: It can be a very demanding course for those who want it. Great selection of books, great conversation.

This class was just a gift. Steph does one of the most difficult and valuable things for an instructor to do: carefully weave together a depth of insight that continually pushes us to add nuance to our ideas while also holding a space of such joy! I think this is one of the best seminars I have taken at Yale and that is because of a combination of Steph, the material we were able to read, and the students in the class.
Strength is the class environment. Weakness is the early time and lack of a break

The reading list for this course is absolutely phenomenal. Steph also had us do smaller research tasks for several (but not all) of the classes. These helped a lot with class engagement and sparked discussion in our seminar meetings. The only weakness is purely logistical: several of the novels we read were challenging to purchase. The bookstore couldn't get them for one reason or another and the library only had a copy or two. This meant that Steph had to photocopy her edition and post the pdf. This was fine, but it often meant that it was impossible to get the book earlier than the week of the class meeting.
This course has only strengths! All members of the seminar engaged fully and discussions were natural, despite the online format.

This course had a very strong syllabus, and the texts were really engaging. I almost wish we had one or two less books on it, so that we could have discussed some of the other novels in more detail than in the time we had.

The class discussions for this course were always insightful and provided me with new ways of understanding the novels we read. From time to time (not often), I'd lose the vein of discussion a bit because of how theoretical it could be.

A full book a week with critical essays during a pandemic was ridiculous. There was simply too much work, and feigning engagement for a 2 hour zoom seminar was near impossible every week. The assigned essays and novels were good, but that means little when its so difficult to finish them for class.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I think the course was rather demanding in the context of COVID. While the professor was understanding on a case-by-case level, she didn't seem to recognize the general atmosphere of stress, exhaustion, and anxiety that students are operating under.

Even when we didn't have a formal assignment, every week there was an optional discussion board to share informal ideas and reflections on the books we read and - at least with this class - it was very effective and the comments always set us up for a very strong class discussion.
A break during the 2 hour seminar

All of the side tasks were really helpful. We also made incredible use of the chat bar in zoom. It was so helpful for comments that were related to things people had said previously or for posting links to articles, etc. All of us wished we could have a chat bar in classes meeting in person.
The class made use of the chat function to extend tangential discussions, which was effective.

I think that the senior seminar requirement as well as reading each week across the English major should have been significantly amended because of the pandemic. Both in Prof. Newell's class and beyond.
The online seminar format worked great. I liked how Steph asked us to unmute our microphones to better simulate an in-person seminar experience.

lol there was nothing in this class geared towards learning during a pandemic. in fact, if it weren't for the fact that class was held over zoom, one might not know that there was anything going on outside of the classroom at all.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Absolutely. This was a fantastic group of readings taught by a thoughtful and charismatic professor. Highly recommend.

Overwhelmingly yes! You read amazing literature and think about it in interesting ways that sheds light on a new way of conceptualizing the world outside of the western canon. There is such a powerful tradition in African storytelling that exists in a parallel form of knowledge production that Steph is so brilliant at guiding you towards. And if that isn't argument enough, Steph is just wonderful!
Yeah, great professor!
Absolutely yes! Such an incredible course with amazing texts you wouldn't get to read in other courses. Prof Newell is engaging and kind and truly believes in your work.
Absolutely, any class with Steph is worth taking.
Yes! Professor Newell is a ray of sunshine, and truly cares about the subject matter. The rigor of discussion truly helped me look at literature in new ways.
I would recommend this to students who are interested in African literature. However it is a little more demanding than an average seminar, so it's important to be really engaged with the work.
Yes! Great texts, awesome discussion week after week.
nope. this course might be interesting in a "normal" semester. regardless, I'm put off by the lack of compassion from professor Newell.
